br.h3: Setup a Local Cassandra for Development
br.p: Now there are several different ways to setup a Cassandra cluster. I will be configuring my local Cassandra instance using Docker. We can do this using Docker Compose and the official Cassandra Image. We can then specify in our docker-compose.yml the following.

pre.code: version: "3" services: cassandra: image: cassandra:3 ports: - "9160:9160" - "9042:9042" volumes: - cassandra-persistence:/var/lib/cassandra volumes: cassandra-persistence:

br.p: We can then start it using docker-compose up and connect to it using cqlsh

pre.code: > docker run -it --rm --net host cassandra:3 cqlsh Connected to Test Cluster at 127.0.0.1:9042. [cqlsh 5.0.1 | Cassandra 3.11.6 | CQL spec 3.4.4 | Native protocol v4] Use HELP for help. cqlsh> DESC KEYSPACES

br.p: This command may seem a bit odd at first, especially if this is your first time working with Docker, so let me break it down.

ul.li: run - specifying that we want to run a container.
-it - specifies we want the launched container to be in interactive mode and we want to attach a TTY session.
--rm - a quality of life flag that will destroy the launched container on termination.
--net host - set the containers networking to that of the host machine. This way we can connect to other containers through our computer network and not a virtual docker network.
cassandra:3 - use the latest image with a Cassandra major version of 3.
cqlsh - the command we want to launch in the container.

br.p: While we could use the same Cassandra instance we created above for Unit Testing it will probably cause us more pain than it's worth. By choosing to use our local Cassandra we will run into issues of consistency. The database can be modified during the execution of UnitTests leading to some unexpected errors. Not to mention it makes our code less portable as it will require a local Cassandra to be configured correctly everywhere we want to run our unit tests.

To get around this, we can use an embedded cassandra server. By using an embedded server we have more control over the database and can specify our CQL scripts to run before and after each unit test. Some examples would be for populating test data or recreating a keyspace before the next test is run.
To get started we can add the following dependencies to our build.gradle.kts file.

Cassandra Unit will create an embedded cassandra server for our unit if we mark the tests with some annotations. Some of the annotations provided can be seen further below. It is important to note that this embedded server does not start on the default 9042 port so we need to specify which port to use in our test application.properties file

After we have completed that, we can then add the following annotations to our src/test/kotlin/io/pragmaticdev/untidy/UntidyApplicationTests.kt to tell spring to load our embedded cassandra before loading the application context.

content.p: As I talked about in my first post, the goal of this blog is to build a program/app/service, whatever you want to call it, to demonstrate building a full-scale application from the requirements to production.

First, before we begin any programming, we need to define what kind of program we are going to build. Given that most of my professional experience is in API Development and Data Engineering, I wanted something that will evolve into those two areas. At a high level, these are some of the requirements.

ul.li: Must be able to interact with the service through a RESTful API.
It must be extendable to later include analytics and data processing.
As stated before, the project also needs to be realistic. We want to build something that people can use.

content.p: Now, given those requirements for the project I have decided that we will build a URL Shortening Service, UnTidy.cc.

URL Shortening is the process of taking long URL's and converting them into something typically shorter than the original URL that points to the same resource. A few popular ones that already exist are TinyURL and Bit.ly.
For example, we can take
And turn it into something much more manageable
These shorter URLs can then be shared in emails, SMS, tweets, or even verbally.
For the most part I will be taking much of this design, and modifying it to suit our needs.
These describe how the core interactions with our service should behave.

ol.li: Given a URL, our service should generate a shorter and unique alias. This needs to short enough that you can tell someone it verbally.
Accessing the short URL should redirect the user to the original link.
Generate links should expire after a default timespan. This value should also be customizable.
Our service should also be accessible through REST APIs by other services.

content.p: These are additional requirements that are not part of the core functionality of the service but are realistic expectations for the service.

ol.li: The system should be highly available. This is required because, if our service is down, all the URL redirections will start failing.
URL redirection should happen in real-time with minimal latency.
Shortened links should not be guessable (not predictable).

content.p: For now, I will just broadly introduce one of our extended requirements that we will further define later on.

ol.li: Analytics; e.g., how many times has redirection happened?. This is part of our extension into the data engineering realm.

content.p: This project I will adopt the JVM Ecosystem (Java and Kotlin), and the Spring Boot Framework. The reasons for these choices are:

ol.li: Java is largely considered the "Enterprise Language" and "No one ever got fired for choosing Java".
Batteries included. Spring has a well-supported ecosystem and provides a lot of functionality out of the box for building production-grade services.

content.p: As stated in the original design we know the following:

ol.li: We need to be able to store up to billions of records.
There are very few relationships between objects. Currently, we only need to store which user created the URL.

content.p: Knowing this information, we can pick a NoSQL database for our storage. For this I have chosen Apache Cassandra. The purpose of choosing a NoSQL database is the need to store up to billions of entries and to be able to scale it horizontally. We could have also chosen several other types of NoSQL stores such as DynammoDB, Redis, or MongoDB but I have opted for Cassandra as the primary store. In future posts, we may see Redis (or Memcached) make an appearance for caching systems.

Since we are using Cassandra, data is commonly denormalized to be able to answer queries with the minimum number of reads. Assuming most of our traffic is just looking up the key and returning the original URL, we do not need the complete user information to return the result to the user. Thus, in the event where we do need to grab the complete user information for a given key, we can simply perform an additional query using the user_id. If you are interested in learning more about why data is denormalized in Cassandra, check out this blog post.
Last but not least, we need to define how we will generate a short URL given a URL. We will be implementing the algorithm in two phases.

To simplify things in the beginning we will start by encoding provided URL by calculating its unique hash using md5 or SHA256 and then encoding its hash value using a custom encoding similar to base64. We will use the alphabet of "23456789abcdefghijkmnpqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHJKLMNPQRSTUVWXYZ"1, 56 characters in total, to avoid confusing similar terms such as 0Ol1ol and the URL path separator of /, and the + symbol since it is commonly used as a space separator in human-friendly URLs.
Now that we have defined the alphabet for our lookup keys, we need to decide on how many characters we want to use to represent the value.

Using this table and "The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two", we can settle comfortably on using 6-8 characters for up to a total of almost ~97 trillion combinations. Assuming the number of combinations was our only limiting factor, we could sustain generating ~307,000 URLs/sec for the next 2 years! We can of course also gradually ramp up the number of character from 6 to 8 over the lifetime of the service, so early adopters will end up with slightly shorter URLs until we run out.

Eventually after many URLs have been hashed, stored, and this service undoubtedly becomes more popular, the frequency of collision for generating our hashes will also increase. This increase in collisions will increase the latency to respond to each request and put more strain on our database by continually querying to see if the generated key has already been allocated to a URL. We will also begin to encounter issues with ensuring we have a lock on the key before continuing.

To deal with this, we will separate the hash/key management into its a separate service. This way the service can continually generate new keys in the background whenever we begin running low and it will be able to provide each instance of our service with a local cache of keys that are known to be not in use. This will help to eliminate the latency caused by collisions and decrease our response time since we will no longer need to generate the key ourselves. One caveat though is if an instance of the shortening service dies, any keys that were assigned to it will be considered dead as well. In the future we can also look into reclaiming these "lost" keys as well.
